posts.name: Abigail Gonzalez
posts.cooked: I just became the new software lead, but mostly because all of our programmers graduated. Because of this, I’m pretty nervous about leadership and don’t have many ideas on what to do in this off-season. I want to hear all of your ideas so that we can start working immediately and grow our skills. Also, this is my first time on ChiefDev, sorry if the tags are wrong.

posts.name: Ben Kallhoff
posts.cooked: Similar situation here, I’m trying to focus on teaching younger team members to avoid this situation in the future.

We plan to focus on improving our understanding of simulation and command-based programming, as our team has been using timed robots and aims to modernize our approach. We also intend to teach these concepts to team members interested in programming, especially since several individuals are eager to learn. This initiative will allow us to build a strong foundation for future projects and ensure everyone is prepared for upcoming challenges.

As 9436 Software Team, this offseason, we worked on developing a robot and simulation until the mechanical team finished the test chassis. During our robot simulation work, we also focused on a project to align all reefs with a single button, which can be found in the following topic: Reefscape one-button automatic alignment. Our code is available in this repository: [GitHub](https://github.com/Giro-FRC/AdvantageKitSwerve). If you have any questions, feel free to ask.

link_counts.title: GitHub - Giro-FRC/AdvantageKitSwerve: AdvantageKitSwerve in off season

posts.name: Eric (319)
posts.cooked: Knowing where and how to find solutions online for software problems, such as locating information about WPI Lib documentation, what it contains, where APIs are located, and how to navigate them, is essential. Additionally, identifying available tools and understanding how they are used is important. Understanding the basics of various programming languages like C++, Java, Python, and Kotlin is crucial. Command-based programming concepts, particularly factory methods, are also key, especially if someone is accustomed to the older command-line paradigm. Logging and visualization tools, like those from an advantage kit, can significantly enhance your workflow. Learning how PID control works and best practices for tuning PID gains is valuable, especially when teaching new students. All this information can generally be found on WPILib or specific product/application documentation.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: One thing that’s under-valued and always worth time investment is fault detection. There’s a WordPress library pull request for a working resistance detection algorithm that’s been stagnant for years due to a lack of real-world testing.

link_counts.title: [wpilib] Add class to calculate robot resistance by calcmogul · Pull Request #5500 · wpilibsuite/allwpilib · GitHub

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked:
In determining the right approach for your team, it’s crucial to establish a strong foundation with a reliable vision system. A chassis robot equipped with cameras can be a great tool for testing vision-related code, though it may not perfectly replicate the performance of a competition robot. Key steps include finding a camera configuration that works for your team through simulations, experimenting with different resolutions, selecting appropriate coprocessors, and aiming for precise and efficient pose estimation. Ensure your camera placements align with the positioning of the AprilTags on the field, allowing for adjustments once the season begins. Consistently refining and improving your vision processing to avoid data loss and prioritize accuracy is equally important. Exploring various filtering options and becoming deeply familiar with your system will enhance both reliability and performance.

When it comes to autonomous driving, focus on refining your alignment and path-following algorithms. Using a chassis bot, experiment with autoalignment and path generation to achieve smoother control during autonomous operations. For control systems, explore different configurations and gain experience with subsystems like state-space control and PID controllers. Reviewing past code can reveal valuable insights, especially identifying areas for future-proofing to prevent costly last-minute changes, like rewriting large portions of code due to overlooked design choices. Establishing robust logging systems, such as using tools like Advantage Scope, can help track progress and troubleshoot efficiently.

Maximizing the use of simulations is another smart strategy, allowing you to identify and fix issues early before building the actual robot. Thoroughly document the APIs and resources available to you to save time troubleshooting. Lastly, prepare thoroughly for new team members by ensuring experienced team members can quickly mentor newcomers, maintaining continuity and expertise within the team.

posts.name: Josh
posts.cooked: Investing time into vision and logging is beneficial. Reprogramming robots, whether focusing on this year’s or last year’s models, is a worthwhile effort. Ensuring the bot is designed as a swerve bot can simplify operations. Consider exploring codes related to wrists, arms, elevators, or various sensors to enhance functionality. Additionally, working on LED projects offers creative potential, providing practical wiring experience and serving as an engaging side project.

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked: The original version was posted in April 2022. It works in simulation, so it just needs someone with an actual robot to test it in real life. It seems the lack of user interest is why it hasn’t been used for three years, so I wouldn’t expect anyone to use it even if we do merge the code.

posts.name: Eric (319)
posts.cooked: It’s important to review past code to identify patterns and learn from previous experiences. Looking at how others approach their work can spark curiosity and inspire new ideas. Examining different coding styles and standards has also been a valuable way to refine my own practices.

posts.name: Val DiBona
posts.cooked: We had designed a public auto alignment system. A major thing we are going to do during the upcoming offseason is simplify and generalize the code so it can be reused from year to year.

posts.name: Samjackjoetedpaulbill
posts.cooked: Don’t just use LEDs for style; they should ideally be designed to stay visible during gameplay, providing real-time feedback to the driver about the robot’s status. This includes key events such as when a game piece is acquired, an April tag is detected, auto-alignment is completed, or if the game piece becomes stuck. Such feedback is crucial for minimizing downtime, quickly identifying the nature and severity of issues, and allowing adjustments to the strategy accordingly—for example, determining whether the intake is malfunctioning due to a voltage spike, whether pivoting to another game piece is feasible, or if switching to Drive mode is necessary because only the drivetrain is operational, or if the vision system is experiencing problems requiring the driver to switch to manual mode.

posts.name: Josh
posts.cooked: That's definitely a good idea to get it under your belt for future use. Personally, we added LEDs to last year's robot to get a grip on things, and it looked awesome.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
To improve your ability to lead the team, consider working on the following projects:

1. Gain proficiency in simulation tools and Mechanism2D models to enable your team to program without needing physical hardware.
2. Develop and implement a robot with a design more complex than what your team achieved last season.
3. Reimagine your current robot using different programming paradigms, such as finite state machines, command-oriented systems, partial state machines, or completely revising the code if it’s significantly flawed.
4. Address the challenges your team faced last season, such as autonomous navigation, vision systems, path planning, or sensor integration, either resolving them differently or exploring alternative approaches.
5. Implement an innovative feature inspired by something you’ve seen in other teams’ robots.
6. Repeat this process, focusing on improving one area at a time and aiming for satisfactory results before moving on to the next project.

The goal is to expand your team’s skill set while staying relevant to the challenges you’re likely to face next year. This approach helps identify common issues others may encounter and provides effective solutions. Once everyone is comfortable with the fundamentals, focus on advanced topics to elevate your program’s capabilities.

For leadership development, consider organizing local workshops or events to assist others. Leading such sessions can help you understand common struggles, offering valuable insights into addressing beginner-level challenges and fostering growth without overwhelming participants. These experiences also provide opportunities to network and strengthen your own skills.
